entry.title: Re: Autosubmission of empty timesheets
entry.content:
Hi @ManonH 

To get untouched empty timesheets picked up, I would suggest you consider doing the following:

First, define a Time Sheet Submission Rule in Admin Center that explicitly includes timesheets with zero entries. This means building rule criteria that accept timesheets even when no time records exist.

Then assign the rule you created to a Time Recording Submission Configuration which is linked to your employees' Time Recording Profile an example will be one for Overtime recording.

Optionally, you can leverage the Time Recording Calendar feature to trigger submission on scheduled dates, which can help cover untouched timesheets.

You then need to confirm there are no pending approvals or errors blocking submission.

Finally, if your current rule includes “no entries” conditions but still does not auto submit untouched timesheets, please verify the rule logic and its assignment to the profile and submission configuration.

 

Below are useful references that will help you with more detailed information:

  • 2738965 - Time Sheet Automatic Submission and Workflow Processing Behaviour (SAP KBA)
  • Automatic Submission of Time Sheets (SAP Help Portal)

 

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance: Send PDF with XML file via email to your business partner
entry.content: @GCET Hi Gaspar! The Business Rule Framework Plus (BRF+) and the Output Parameter Determination (OPD) are not used in this process. The service is configured via REST APIs. The email address is configured in the business system. Regards, Thiago.

entry.title: Re: How to upload data from excel to the database tables
entry.content:
Given your upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to 2023, and the need to restore data from Excel backups if any loss occurs, here's a recommended approach that balances business integrity and technical safety:

Direct updates to database tables bypass SAP’s application logic, risking:

  • Data inconsistency
  • Broken referential integrity
  • Audit and compliance issues

Below would be the Business Process considerations

From the Technical point of view, SAP provides several safe and supported ways to upload Excel data:

Most importantly, validate before Upload by comparing Excel backup with post-upgrade data, use ABAP logic to highlight missing records, Only upload delta records after approval

Again and again, the final advice is that even in upgrade scenarios, never update SAP tables directly via SQL or SE16N. Instead, use application-layer tools that respect SAP’s data model and business rules.

entry.title: Function Expression in Business Rule Framework (BRF+)
entry.content:
Function in BRF+:

A function is the rule interface in BRF+ and acts as a link between the application code and the BRF+ code. A function carries a context and a result. It imports the context from the calling application and passes the context data to the assigned top expression or ruleset for further processing.

Create an BRF+ application or chose the application in which you wanted to add function Expression. 

Right click on the application and select create > Function 

 

Provide the function name, text and short text.

Click on create and navigate to object to save and activate the object.  

 

Once clicked, it will navigate to the above screen. Here you have to assign the result data object based on the context data objects. 

Types of Mode: 

Function mode: 

In functional mode, function execution starts with the assigned top expression. From this top expression, the processing may run through any number of nested subexpressions until a result is returned.  

Event mode: 

In event mode, the function is associated with a list of rulesets that are executed according to their execution priority and their position in the list. 

Function and Event mode:

This mode is a combination of the modes mentioned above. At runtime, the function starts processing the assigned top expression. Once the expression evaluation is finished, function execution continues with the associated rulesets. 

Analytical Mode: 

It is mainly related to the Hana rules framework which is relevant to the runtime operations. 

 Signature

The function signature consists of two parts: 

  • Context 

The context is a container for data objects that you can assign as import parameters for the function. You choose the context data objects of a function according to the requirements of the calling application by which the BRF+ function is invoked. Also, the context data objects of a function define the scope of objects that can be accessed by the expressions that are evaluated during function execution. 

  • Result 

The result data object returns a result value that has been calculated by the expressions of which the function consists . 

Note: For further in event mode, the result object is automatically set to the predefined actions table where the actions are recorded that have been triggered by the assigned rulesets. 

Code Generation:

BRF+ provides a built-in code generation facility used to compile source code for as many rule constructs in a function as possible. With the help of generated code, BRF+ rules can be executed significantly faster than in interpretation mode. 

Simulation: 

You can simulate the function processing to test the function's behavior in a sandbox environment. Here, you can gain an in-depth insight into the system status for every single step the system takes during function processing. 

Trace

In BRF+, you can request the system to create a processing log to keep track of all processing steps during function execution. The trace information is stored in the system and can be reviewed at any point in time. 

Trace will be stored in Trace tables FDT_TRACE_*

Generation Services

For a BRF+ function, you can take advantage of different services that automatically generate code and other objects that are needed to bridge the gap between the ABAP backend system where a BRF+ function is hosted and other systems or environments that wish to access BRF+. The different services available address different usage scenarios. These can be categorized as follows: 

  • Code Templates 

A code template is a predefined snippet of ABAP code that you can use to call a BRF+ function from your application in the same system. 

  • Generate  
  • Function Module 

You can use a generated RFC-enabled function module to call a BRF+ function that resides in a remote backend system. This is useful in cases where you cannot bring BRF+ and the calling application into the same system — be it for technical reasons (for example, different releases) or for organizational reasons (for example, missing authorization to develop in the remote system). 

  • Web Service 

You can use a generated web service to call a BRF+ function from a web application that is not ABAP-based, or that you can only integrate via its exposed services interface. From a technical point of view, web service generation is reusing the function module generation component of BRF+ and generates additional system objects needed for service enablement. 

Here we will work on Function mode example: 

 

Assign the top expression and in context add the required objects and finally assign result object suitable. 

Top Expression:  

Its is pre-condition of the function which will evaluate the number of nested expressions to find the result. 

To execute the function click on simulation. 

Click on continue 

Select the input true or false and click on execute 

Result : 

Note : All the objects created will be stored in FDT_* tables 

Conclusion: 

Function provides a built-in code generation facility used to compile source code for as many rule constructs in a function as possible
Function is the most important BRF+ object and it represents a decision service , which is the element that is in fact invoked by the application and the entire application is invoked by function to stimulate and provide the output we can invoke using the code generation to create report program for executing in GUI.
we can perform pre-conditional and event of action related condition's like rules for executing in the based on the specified rule using the type of modes in the function expression.

entry.title: Workflow condition for Purchase Order – How to read Plant at creation time in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Everyone.

I am working in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and have created a custom workflow for Purchase Orders in Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders.
The workflow has 2 steps and should be triggered only if the Plant = 1000.

I am implementing the BAdI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF to define and evaluate a custom start condition.
In the EVALUATE_CONDITION method, I can easily check the Plant for an already saved PO using i_purchaseorderitemapi01.
Example:

SELECT * FROM i_purchaseorderitemapi01 WHERE purchaseorder = @IS_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1 INTO TABLE @LT_items.

Problem:
When the PO is being created for the first time (in draft mode),

  • is_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1 is empty (no PO number yet).

  • There is no CDS view like i_purchaseorderitemapidraft to read the plant directly.

  • So I cannot determine the plant at creation time to set cv_is_true for triggering the workflow.

Question:

  • How can I get the Plant information for a PO at the time of creation (before it has a PO number) inside SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF in S/4HANA Public Cloud?

  • Is there a draft table or API available for reading the data?


I found some other custom logic where I am getting plant data, but there I have no changing parameter which evaluates Workflow triggering condition. 

I found below 2 business context BADI definition & Implementation feasible for Workflow triggering.

SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF => Condition Definition
SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL => Business Logic Validation
Except these I found no other feasible business context custom logic for workflow triggering.

How to achieve the above requirement
SAP S/4HANA Cloud ABAP Environment SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere Data Access Control Hierarchy with Dir...
entry.content:
Hi to everyone,

I had some troubles creating a DAC Hierarchy with directory which I posted here a few days ago. This solution might help you understanding the values for the permission table. Please let me know if there is better solution for creating a DAC Hierarchy with Directory. Thanks!

 

Goal of the DAC Hierarchy with Directory:

User X gets access only to the US Cost Center Shared Services.

Approach:

  1. Test your Hierarchy with Directory:

Make sure, the hierarchy with directory is working properly. The HwD has at least 4 artefacts. Controlling Area and Cost Center are the mapping fields for associating the DAC later on.

2. Preview in Analytic Model:

It is helpful to have a preview in the Analytic Model before inserting the values in the Permission Table. In the AM you can easily identify the objects you want the user getting access to. Choose the correct hierarchy at first:

Identify the cost center:

3. Permission Table:

3.1: Restriction

One or more 0 restrictions per user act as an AND condition

0 and 1 restrictions per user act as an OR condition

3.2: Target Node Type

The target object was identified in the AM as a leaf. The value "L" identifies the columns which are needed to map the DAC later on. 

3.3: Root Node Type

The target object L is under the node type N (here, N and R have the same columns). 

3.4: Root Values

Are the compound values of CostCEnterHierarchy (Column 1) and HierarchyNode (Colum 2). You have to insert the actual value of these columns. Note, that you have to add a backslash between the values: "0101/A000/A000\01710110"

3.5: Hierarchy Identifier

Identifies which hierarchy the target objects belong to (here: the cost center belongs to the first hierarchy)

  1. 0101/A000/A000
  2. F101/A000/CCH

4. Create the DAC:

Add the permission table in the Permission Entity.

The Identifier Column is the USER_ID defined in the permission table.

Mapp all columns to the Criteria and add the Hierarchy with Directory. 

Select the Node Type "L" as the target objects are leaf nodes:

5. Associate the DAC to the Fact view GL Account Line Item:

The defined user will have restricted access to the cost center:

 

Mapping:

6. Create AM:

 

Note:

In the Preview of the fact view, there is an error message "Duplicate key predicate". This won't be the case when you open the Preview of the AM.

 

The AM Preview shows the US Cost Center for Shared Services now:

entry.title: Issue with Form Language in Billing Document Output Items
entry.content:
Dear SAP Experts,

As part of the billing document management process, we are facing an issue related to the form generated in the output items.

In the Form Country/Region field, SAP is retrieving the language from the Business Partner instead of using the form language maintained in the Output Parameter Determination (OPD) application.

I have checked the OPD configuration, and the form language is correctly set to French (FR). However, in our case, the form was generated with Spain as the country (BP country). With this, the form appears in $ currency, which is not correct. 


Could you please advise?

Thank you for your help.

entry.title: Re: Business partner transaction records restriction
entry.content:
@amer_alsharif wrote:

Dear,

how to restrict view a specific business partner id transaction records  in sap public 4hana,

I have business partner id and in manage/view supplier invoices all users can using this app but i want to restrict view all supplier invoices that related to this business partner id to be visible for a specific users.

thanks for your feedback.

Hello,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can restrict the view of specific business partner transaction records by using the "Maintain Business Roles" app. You'll need to create or modify a business role to include restrictions based on business partner ID. This involves setting up a custom role with a specific "Write/Read" access filter for the relevant app (e.g., "Manage Supplier Invoices") and defining the business partner ID as a key restriction parameter. Assigning this new role to specific users will then limit their access to only the transactions associated with the designated business partner.

entry.title: Re: Behavior validation messages are not displayed
entry.content:
Hello Patrick

not sure if you found already a solution for the problem on your own. After some research and trial and error i found a solution on our release (S4HANA onPrem 2023).

To force the request for state messages from frontend, you have to add for the action (in your case Draft-Action PREPARE) that is initially triggered for the generation of messages a side effect which affects messages in the behavior definition. Here you then have various options to define e.g. the field or the entity that is used in a validation. So all of the fields or entities (or $self -> for the root entity) must not only be definied in the validation, but also in the side effect with an effect on messages, otherwise the messages were not shown in my case. 

If this not leads to success, also consider to adjust the CONSUMPTION BEHAVIOR DEFINITION with the extension of  

use side effects;

on top level.

i adjusted your initial version of the behavior with the corresponding side effect

 

managed implementation in class zbp_i_product unique;
strict ( 2 );
with draft;

define behavior for ZI_Product alias product
persistent table za_product
draft table zd_product
authorization master ( instance )
lock master
total etag LastChangedAt
etag master LastChangedAt
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;

  field ( mandatory ) ProductName;
  field ( readonly, numbering : managed ) ProductUuid;
  field ( readonly ) CreatedBy, CreatedAt, LastChangedBy, LastChangedAt;

  validation validateMandatoryFields on save { field ProductName create; }

  mapping for za_product
    {
      ProductUuid = product_uuid;
      ProductName = product_name;
      ProductType = product_type;
      CreatedBy = created_by;
      CreatedAt = created_at;
      LastChangedBy = last_changed_by;
      LastChangedAt = last_changed_at;
    }

  draft determine action Prepare
  {
    validation validateMandatoryFields;
  }
// The side effect forces the frontend to request the messages (SAP__messages) in OData call
  side effects
  {
    determine action Prepare executed on field ProductName affects messages;
  }
  draft action Edit;
  draft action Activate optimized;
  draft action Discard;
  draft action Resume;

}

entry.title: Re: IDOC/ALE best practise to Build IDOC_DATA(EDIDD) in ABAP
entry.content:
Thanks für all answers, for me as non nativ speaker it is difficult to write a question in the way people know what i mean.

I think the best design in a greenfield-appreach is to generate the ALF-Interface with Transaktion BDFG. In doing so you have another layer of seperation in filling a deep structure with dedicated data elements first and then generating the IDOC_DATA.

However my szenario is Brownfield so I build the IDOC_DATA line by line, however with more new abap-Syntax:

DATA: lt_idoc_data TYPE idoc_data.
    TRY.
        INSERT VALUE edidd( segnam  = 'Z1XXXXX'
                            sdata   = myobject->Z1XXXXX( ...) ) INTO TABLE lt_idoc_data.

        INSERT VALUE edidd( segnam  = 'Z1YYYYY'
                            sdata   = myobject->map_Z1YYYYY( ... ) ) INTO TABLE lt_idoc_data.

      CATCH zcx_mapping_exxor INTO DATA(lo_cx).
"Fill Bal Log(...)
endtry.

Mapping of the structures i delegate to a dedicated member-Object.

entry.title: ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
End of 2022 we launched ABAP Cloud and published the new ABAP extensibility guide. This guide is the best starting point for overview of ABAP Cloud development model and ABAP-based extensibility options for SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on-premise. The last update of the extensibility guide took place in May 2023 where we incorporated the feedback of early adaptors of ABAP Cloud in real SAP S/4HANA systems.

A key concept for extensibility in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on-premise outlined in the ABAP extensibility guide was the 3-tier extensibility model. This model described how ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP can co-exist within a single system: tier 1 contained ABAP Cloud on-stack extensions, as well as any developments with SAP Build on SAP BTP for side-by-side extensions. Tier 2 served to address gaps, providing mechanisms to mitigate necessary publicly released SAP APIs not yet available in tier 1. Finally, tier 3 encompassed classic ABAP extensions. Only tier 1 (and tier 2, when using recommended SAP objects) was considered as clean core. In contrast, tier 3 was classified as “not clean.” The ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness controlled the usage of classic ABAP in custom extensions.

The main objective of the clean core dimension Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA on-premise deployments is decoupling of custom extensions from SAP standard via use of ABAP Cloud and reliable development and extension technologies to reach upgrade stability. On the way to clean core, dealing with the classic ABAP custom code represents a challenge for SAP customers and partners. Multiple customer and partner interactions showed that the binary classification of custom code in the 3-tier extensibility model in “clean core” and “not clean core” and governance based on ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness were too restrictive and not applicable for systems with a lot of existing custom code developed with classic ABAP. Besides this there are also new custom extensions which need to be implemented with classic ABAP because for example the related SAP application area is not sufficiently covered by publicly released SAP APIs or is implemented with SAP GUI based technologies and frameworks. On the other hand, many of underlying SAP classic ABAP technologies, like ABAP List Viewer for example, incorporate an implementation stability which most likely will bring minimum upgrade risks and can be still utilized in classic ABAP developments.

The new Clean core extensibility white paper introduced by SAP incorporates evolution of the current 3-tier extensibility model with binary decisions on clean core to more detailed assessment of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept, allowing you as SAP customers and partners stepwise transformation to clean core at your own pace.

In a nutshell:

  • Level A are the cleanest custom extensions built either on-stack with ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side using any option of SAP Build on SAP BTP – ABAP Cloud, CAP or low-code/no-code tools

           Levels B-D relate to all classic ABAP developments and can be reached as follows:

  • Level B can be achieved by custom extensions that comply with SAP recommendations for the use of classic ABAP development technologies and the frameworks offered as classic SAP APIs
  • Level C contains custom extensions which cannot be qualified for Level B because of usage of arbitrary SAP internal objects. Under the condition that dedicated checks are performed before the release upgrade (following the changelog for SAP objects approach), these custom extensions can be considered conditionally clean.
  • Level D is not clean core and includes custom extensions with severe violations of SAP development recommendations like modifications, usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension technologies (e.g. implicit enhancements).

Following the new clean core extensibility guidance we have updated the ABAP extensibility guide with technical guidelines which are in line and support the clean core level concept for the classification of custom extensions.

Summary of technical ABAP extensibility guidelines for clean core


How the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) supports clean core level concept

Main updates for transformation of 3-tier extensibility model to clean core extensibility based on clean core level concept (see the activity log on page 1 of the ABAP extensibility guide for details):

  • Change technical guidelines for extensibility from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development and classic ABAP development
  • Explain classic SAP APIs and their matching to clean core levels
  • Provide ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of classic ABAP development for clean core
  • Explain relation of custom code use cases to clean core levels
  • Describe changelog for SAP objects approach for assessment of upgrade stability of custom code using SAP internal objects
  • Change transformation options for existing custom code from 3-tier extensibility model to ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP developments

Supporting the clean core extensibility and clean core level concept with these technical guidelines for ABAP extensibility is a next significant step forward to support your clean core transformation at your own speed.

If you have already set up the 3-tier extensibility model and are following clean core development practices, you might be wondering if the new guidance changes everything. Good news — you are already on the right track! The new clean core level concept simply provides enhanced guidance for everything you developed in tier 3 with classic ABAP.

If you now want to learn more about the refined clean core extensibility guidance and clean core levels, read the Clean core extensibility whitepaper.

For more information about ABAP Cloud and recommendations for classic ABAP developments, classic APIs, ABAP test cockpit setup and behavior for governance of clean core development supporting the clean core levels switch directly to the updated ABAP extensibility guide.

In addition, you can also use the updated ABAP Cloud - Extensibility slide deck . To get your questions answered use the ABAP Cloud FAQ and the ABAP Development community.

We will continue our ABAP Cloud and clean core collaboration with customers and partners and will share the new learnings and provide new updates. After this update related to the adaption of the new clean core extensibility model the next major update of the ABAP extensibility guide planned for Q4/2025 will focus on enhancements in ABAP custom code management tools and ABAP AI capabilities. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Re: MULTIPLE FG & COMMON SFG
entry.content:
If SFG01 is consumed by multiple FGs:

  • You’ll find multiple RESB entries for the same MATNR = 'SFG01' but different AUFNR
  • You need to aggregate quantities per FG order, per date, per plant

entry.title: Is there anyway to cancel the VAT portion of an AP invoice which has been posted in error
Re: Public Cloud Payment medium file - Hash total calcula...
entry.content:
Hello @Sandhya_Reddy1 

In SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, you can’t use ABAP exits or BAdIs for payment mediums.
To add a hash total in a .txt file, you must:

  • Copy the payment medium format to Manage Payment Medium Formats.
  • Create an accumulator in the format tree to sum amounts or count items.
  • Map that accumulator to a footer/control record field.
  • Test via Manage Automatic Payments.

This is a standard-supported method in Public Cloud. 

SAP Help Portal – Maintain Payment Medium Formats (S/4HANA Cloud)

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SSO Configuration Issue When Accessing S/4HANA Public...
entry.content:
Hi @Chris1973,

Thanks for your reply. I reviewed the configuration again, but the same error still occurs.
I confirmed that the trust configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service includes both Build Work Zone and the S/4HANA Cloud system.
My understanding is that there’s no need to configure direct trust between Build Work Zone and S/4HANA Cloud; instead, each should be trusted with Cloud Identity Services. Is that correct?
For the trust setup between Build Work Zone and Cloud Identity Services, I used Open ID Connect, as it was officially recommended.
In the destination settings, I changed the authentication method for the destination N5T_Starter_rt_apps from "No Authentication" to "SAML Assertion".
I’m not very familiar with how to configure SAML Assertion, so I referred to the tutorial for N5T_Starter_rt_tiles and applied the same settings. Please let me know if any of the settings are incorrect or if any additional settings are required.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-build-work-zone-integrate-sap-s-4hana-public-cloud-content-to-sap/ba-p/13572886

entry.title: GIS and SAP Integration – critical for Oil and Gas Companies
entry.content:
Dynamic alignment sheets facilitate the maintenance process

Today’s blog focuses on the midstream segment of the oil and gas industry, where the transportation of oil and gas plays a critical role. Companies aim to optimize field asset management by maintaining accurate digital twins of pipelines and related assets. Traditionally, however, different business and IT systems are used to represent these assets: SAP systems manage financial and maintenance data, while GIS systems handle technical specifications and location intelligence. To streamline asset registration and improve efficiency, it is essential to eliminate duplicate data entry, which not only wastes time but also increases the risk of errors.

VertiGIS Integrator streamlines the asset registration process by enabling efficient synchronization between GIS and SAP systems. Assets can be initially created in SAP and synchronized to GIS, where only the geographical location and select technical attributes are recorded. Conversely, for assets where GIS serves as the primary system, the integration ensures these assets are seamlessly transferred to SAP after their creation in GIS. This bi-directional workflow enables a highly efficient and integrated asset registration process.

With GIS and SAP now fully integrated, businesses can leverage map-centric workflows to enhance operational efficiency. A key example is in maintenance processes, particularly the creation of notifications. For instance, when a pipeline malfunction, such as corrosion, is identified in the field, it is essential to pinpoint the exact location along the pipeline for accurate notification placement.

Traditionally, oil and gas companies have relied on alignment sheets to document various properties or events along linear assets using linear references, such as meters or kilometers. VertiGIS has modernized this process with its VertiGIS Inline software module, bringing alignment sheets into the digital era. This module allows users to dynamically analyze pipeline-related data through a combination of standard maps and linear-referenced properties displayed below the pipeline. Using VertiGIS Studio Workflow technology, user actions can be configured through an intuitive drag-and-drop interface. This enables end users to create SAP notifications at specific linear reference points (e.g., kilometer 3.2) or precise map coordinates (X, Y). This map-centric approach simplifies and improves the user experience for creating SAP notifications.

The interface displays the pipeline on a map, with a dynamic alignment sheet below. Users can efficiently create SAP notifications or other custom events at specific points, such as kilometer 3.2.

In addition, VertiGIS supports map-centric mobile workflows that integrate SAP and GIS systems. Field workers can use mobile applications, such as VertiGIS Studio Mobile, to create notifications or manage work orders directly in the field. These notifications are then automatically synced with the SAP system in near real-time, ensuring accurate and up-to-date information across business systems.

If you have any questions or would like to find out more, please contact me at https://www.linkedin.com/in/florianbrandidohrn/ or florian.brandi-dohrn@vertigis.com.

entry.title: Why access to SAP HANA XS Advanced Message Service is denied with condition amqp:illegal-state
entry.content:
Hi, experts!

Working with SAP WEBIDE (of SAP HANA PLATFORM HANA DB 2 SP7 Build - 79.2 DB XSA 1.3.1)

I created multi target application with java module "javaapi".

And mta.yaml file contains such definitions:

...
modules:
...
  - name: javaapi
    type: java
...
    requires:
     - name: msg-service
...
resources:
...
  - name: msg-service
    type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
    parameters:
      service: messaging-service
      service-plan: free

And java module contains such code:

...
import org.apache.qpid.jms.JmsConnectionFactory; 
...
System.out.println("setup jmx connection");
JmsConnectionFactory connectionFactory = new JmsConnectionFactory(cred.url);
Thread.sleep(5000);
System.out.println("create jmx connection");
connection = connectionFactory.createConnection(cred.user, cred.password);
Thread.sleep(5000);
System.out.println("start jmx connection");
connection.start();

And when java module "javaapi" is built, then messaging-service instance "msg-service" is automatically built too, where url and credentials are successfully got.

But at the runtime the last line of java code above (connection.start();) causes such failure:

Open of resource:
(JmsConnectionInfo { ID:..., configuredURI = amqps://..., connectedURI = null })
failed:
Failed to log authentication attempt. Access denied. [condition = amqp:illegal-state]

Can you explain:

why access to SAP HANA XS Advanced Message Service is denied with condition "amqp:illegal-state"

or why "Error is thrown when the peer sent a frame that is not permitted in the current state." (which is the meaning of amqp:illegal-state)

and why there is such state at all (after starting)

as well as how it might be changed (and the problem might be resolved)?

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Partial set-off of down payment against regular custo...
entry.content: Sir, once again, thank you for the detailed reply. I have read through all the points. However, since Project Billing works quite differently in Professional Services, I'm unable to use any of these methods for my requirement. The scenario is such that, initially, the customer makes a down payment of say 1,000,000 INR against our down payment request and we post the incoming payment. Now, the regular invoice is raised on a monthly basis until the end of the project, which could be a few years later. So, when the 1st regular invoice is raised for say 37,500 INR (as shown in the screenshot), we would like to set-off only 50% of 37,500 instead of the complete amount and then post incoming payment from the customer for the balance 50% (18,750 INR). This is a time & expense project, so the invoice is raised on a monthly basis instead of milestones. The billing documents are not auto-generated. As for the PBD, being able to edit the invoice line items and not the down payment lines is not helping us. SAP should allow the user to edit the down payment set-off amount. Thank you once again.

entry.title: Re: IFP OPEX Calculating CCTR Activity Quantities inversely
entry.content:
Hi @SANA11

To populate Data "Zero" on the Measure "QUANTITY" from the below script,

  • DATA([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY") 
    * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DRIVER5", [d/Date] = #D1, [d/SAP_FI_IFP_GLACCOUNT] = "#", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_CODEBITCREDITCODE] = "#", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_PRTNRCOSTCENTER] = "#",
    [d/SAP_FI_IFP_PRTNRCCACTIVITYTYPE] = "#", [d/SAP_FI_IFP_FIXVARIABLE] = "#", [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_PROFITCENTER] = "#", [d/t.S:SAP_ALL_FUNCTIONALAREA] = "#") * 0

First "RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY")" and second "RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DRIVER5", [d/Date] = #D1,...)" should have a Fact Data. Based on the existing Data (QUANTITY & DRIVER5), multiplying by zero (* 0)  generates a zero value in the target scope "DATA([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY")"

If the values of "RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY")" and "RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DRIVER5")" are not available(=Nulll), no zero is generated.
Check whether data exists for RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "QUANTITY") and RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "DRIVER5"). 

The meaning of this data action script is: If there are values for Quantity and Driver5 in the source scope, set the value of Quantity in the target scope to zero. 

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Remove failed requests in Offline Mobile Development...
entry.content:
How to Remove Failed Requests in Offline Mobile Development Kit (MDK) App

When working with the Offline Mobile App Development Kit (MDK) app, failed requests often get stored locally to be retried later. Sometimes, you may want to clear these failed requests manually, especially during development or testing.

Here’s how you can remove failed requests in an Offline MDK app:

  1. Clear the Offline Store Data:

    • The easiest and most straightforward way to remove failed requests is to clear the offline store.

    • This can be done by calling the clearOfflineStore API (if available in your MDK implementation) or by programmatically deleting the local offline store data.

    • For example, in MDK, you might find an API or configuration to reset or clear the offline data, which removes all cached requests including failed ones.

  2. Restart the App / Clear App Data:

    • In many cases, simply uninstalling and reinstalling the app or clearing the app data on the device will remove all locally stored requests, including failed ones.

    • On Android: Go to Settings > Apps > Your MDK App > Storage > Clear Data.

    • On iOS: Uninstall and reinstall the app.

  3. Use App-Specific Features:

    • Some MDK apps provide UI options or admin features to manage offline requests, including clearing failed ones.

    • Check if your app has a “Sync Status” or “Offline Requests” screen with an option to delete or retry failed requests.

  4. Retry or Cancel Requests:

    • If the app supports retrying or canceling offline requests, use those options to clean up failed ones.

    • Canceling failed requests removes them from the retry queue.

  5. Check for Logs or Debug Options:

    • For development, enable debug or logging features in your app to identify and manage failed requests.

    • You can programmatically filter and remove failed requests if your app’s offline logic supports it.

Summary:

  • Clearing offline store or app data is the most direct way to remove failed requests.

  • Look for UI or programmatic options within your MDK app to manage offline requests.

  • Uninstalling and reinstalling the app resets the offline data.

  • For permanent solutions, handle errors gracefully and provide options to cancel or retry requests.

If you are a developer, refer to your specific MDK version’s documentation for APIs related to offline store management.

entry.title: Re: SAP Service request notifications to be sent to email...
entry.content:
At the time, there is currently no way to pre-set a designated contact to receive notifications for all Case/Service Requests. Notifications for Case/Service Requests are based on specific Case/Service Requests. 

For Service Requests, notifications are sent to the original reporter (S-user ID) and any additional contacts added to the specific request. However, it is not possible to designate a default contact for all Service Requests. 

For guidance on managing additional contacts in an open Service Request, please refer to the following KBA: 
3462685 - How to add or delete additional contact in an open Service Request - SAP for Me
 
Similarly, for Case notifications, the S-user who created the case (referred to as the "reporter") will receive notifications. Any S-users added as additional contacts to the case will also be notified.
For more details on what triggers notifications for a case, please see the KBA 2098967 - What triggers notifications for a case? - SAP for Me

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us.

entry.title: Re: Simple RAP based Managed UI development with Create & Delete actions on custom BillDoc heade
entry.content:
Here's a breakdown of the steps involved,

Define the Data Model:

  • Create a package: Organize project resources within a package.
  • Define database tables: For example, tables for employee information, employment details, and position information.
  • Create CDS views: An interface CDS view for a basic view, and a consumption CDS view exposing a subset of elements from the interface view. 

Define the Business Logic:

  • Create a behavior definition: Define actions like Create, Update, Delete, and determine business logic.
  • Implement the behavior: Write the ABAP code for validations, actions, and determinations in the behavior implementation. 

Create the UI:

  • Create a metadata extension: Enhance the CDS view for UI elements.
  • Define service binding: Specify the entities to expose and the protocol (e.g., OData V2 for UI).
  • Publish the service: Make the service available for consumption. 

Test the Application:

  • Preview the service: Use the service to create, read, update, and delete data. 
  • Test the UI: Access the application through a Fiori launchpad or other UI client. 

Advanced Features (Optional):

  • Semantic navigation: Implement navigation between different entities or views.
  • Integration with BAPIs: Use existing BAPIs for data access or processing.
  • Web APIs: Integrate with external web services.
  • Background processing: Implement background jobs for tasks like data processing or report generation.

Instead of canceling the POs, the system should ideally propose rescheduling the PO delivery dates to align with the demand.

entry.title: Re: Excel pop-up window not recognized during BPA scenario on virtual machine
entry.content:
Hi @liskaj01,
Did your issue get resolved?

If not, to keep the VM active, you need to ensure it remains active even after disconnecting your session. We faced a similar issue earlier with UI Automation after disconnecting, the screen was not recognized, and we encountered screen timeout-related errors.

To resolve this, we set the sleep timer to "never" and used a PowerShell script to disconnect from the VM session without affecting the running processes.

Additionally, we noticed that click activities sometimes fail in certain scenarios. In such cases, using the Mouse Click activity instead can help.

entry.title: Proportional Integration - Proportion Shares - Group Reporting
entry.content:
Hello Experts!

I am working with a consolidation perimeter that has companies that consolidate using the full, proportional, and equity methods.

 

I am wondering whether the percentage of ownership for those consolidation units that are consolidated using the proportional consolidation method should be included using Task 2140 - Enter Group Shares (PL30) or whether it should be included in the custom Task 2145 - Enter Proportion Shares % (PL30).

Should it be included in only one of the two, or in both? As I understand it, it must be entered on both sides so that the CoI task can be executed correctly, and then so that the process for FS Items relating to proportional integration can be carried out.

We have based on the file "How to Proportionate Data_V1" attached on https://me.sap.com/notes/2659672

Thank in advance!

SAP S/4HANA Finance for group reporting

entry.title: Missing Migration Objects in Treasury – Any Solutions or Workarounds?
entry.content:
Hi experts,

we are currently implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, release 2508 and have run into a challenge in the Treasury module: several key master data objects are not available as standard migration objects in the SAP Migration Cockpit.

Specifically, we are missing migration templates for:

  • Business Partner – Counterparty role (over 400 records)

  • Loan facility – several hundred entries

  • Assignment of loan to loan facility – applies to 400+ loan transactions

  • Investments – also several hundred entries

From the SAP documentation, it seems that only a limited number of Treasury migration objects are provided (e.g. FX options, interest rate instruments), but not the ones listed above.

This results in a significant amount of manual work – potentially well over 1,000 data records in total would have to be created directly in the productive system.

Questions to the community:

  1. Are there any SAP plans (e.g. CFD delivery) to provide migration objects for these data types in upcoming releases?

  2. Has anyone implemented workarounds – for example, using other migration objects, APIs, RPA, or automation tools – to handle such volumes?

  3. Any best practices for managing this amount of manual effort efficiently?

Thanks a lot for your input!

Best regards,
Robert

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Treasury Management SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Data Migration SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Billing related to reassigned revenues i...
entry.content:
Dear @Max_H_ ,

Regarding your questions I would like to provide following answers

1) Reassign Revenues from one WBS-element to another (different company code) via App: Reassign costs and revenues
Reassignment of revenues across company codes is supported by the App. For intercompany revenue reassignment please acknowledge that this Management Accounting posting will also show up in the Account Line Items and may influence local stat accounting. The intercompany posting in Management Accounting is offset with an ICO clearing account posting.
Please refer to 
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/intercompany-cost-allocations-in-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13442721 
for further details.

2) Create intercompany billing request + invoice
As you mentioned the process for costs is totally fine.
The described behavior for revenues is not supported. The consideration of revenue reassignments is considered as a bug on which is currently being worked upon. Intercompany Billing for Cross Company Cost Accounting postings (4AN) should not be used. Depending on the use case cross company revenue reassignment - in case needed and compliant - other scenarios need to be used (eg manual journal entry).

Best regards
Thorsten

entry.title: Re: MRP Type V1
entry.content:
MRP Type V1 stands for Manual Reorder Point Planning with External Requirements. It behaves differently from standard MRP types like PD:

  • It’s primarily consumption-based, not requirement-driven.
  • It does not perform full rescheduling checks like PD does.
  • It may ignore future reservations if they fall outside the reorder logic or rescheduling horizon.

As a result, when you run MRP with V1:

  • the system may see existing POs as unnecessary if stock is above the reorder point.
  • It may suggest canceling POs even if future reservations exist.

Recommended approach is switch to MRP Type PD (Planning Based on Requirements) which performs rescheduling checks and considers future reservations. It generates exception messages like:

  • 10 – Bring process forward
  • 15 – Postpone process

This ensures POs are rescheduled, not canceled, when demand shifts.

Configure Rescheduling Horizon and Tolerance via transactions OPPQ or OMDW to set:

Rescheduling horizon: Defines how far into the future MRP looks for requirements
Tolerance values: Controls when exception messages are triggered

This helps MRP recognize valid future demand and propose rescheduling instead of deletion.

In short, the summary would be

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I read the below in an article and just need to know if we really have any tools like this in SF.

*****************************************************************************************************************

SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader

  • Use Case: While this isn’t a SAP solution outside of SuccessFactors, it’s an important tool for ensuring that data is in the right format when importing into Employee Central.
  • How it Helps:
    • Data Formatting: SAP SuccessFactors Data Loader requires the data to be in a specific format. Using tools like SAP Data Services or SAP MDG to format the data before uploading can ensure smooth integration.
    • Validation Checks: The Data Loader also performs basic validation checks on the data to ensure that it conforms to SuccessFactors standards before proceeding with the upload.

******************************************************************************************************************************

Appreciate your response on this.

Regards,

SR

entry.title: Re: SSO Configuration Issue When Accessing S/4HANA Public...
entry.content:
Based on your details, yes, your understanding is correct. There is no need to configure direct trust between SAP Build Work Zone and SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Instead, both systems independently establish trust with the same Identity Provider, typically the SAP Cloud Identity Services. Please note, Build Work Zone can authenticate to IAS via OpenID Connect for user login but the backend destination to S/4HANA must use an authentication method that supports token forwarding e.g., SAML Assertion or OAuth 2.0.

The SAML Assertion setup must however, align with IAS and S4HANA trust configurations, including metadata exchange, certificates, and application registration. Which might be the issue here. If you followed the SAML Assertion configuration tutorial for N5T_Starter_rt_tiles, I suggest checking and potentially evaluating the following steps to ensure they are correct:

  • First, make sure the SAML fields like Destination, Audience, Recipient, and NameIdentifier are properly set to match your application settings.
  • Then the SAML response status should indicate success.
  • Also, make sure to Check the certificate used to sign the SAML assertion matches what your app expects.
  • After that, confirm the attributes in the assertion map correctly to what your application requires e.g., email, user id.
  • If needed, adjust attribute mappings in your SAML provider to fit your app's expectations.
  • Finally, ensure logout requests’ SessionIndex and NameID match the original assertion for proper sign-out.

If you still encounter the same error, I suggest you review your SAML/OAuth setup in IAS, destination configuration in BTP, and check token exchange logs on both sides.

Let me know if that works for you.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAC Story - Dropdown for property of Date dimension.
entry.content:
While using an SAC Story on top of a Planning Model, and with the help of @nikhil (link below), I am able to successfully add properties of a generic dimension to a Dropdown widget. I am now wanting to do the same for the Date dimension property "CALMONTH".

However, after copying the working code, and where applicable changing it to use the dimension "Date" and the property "CALMONTH", the dropdown remains unpopulated on initialization.  I have tried using a different Date property and also recreated a new model, but I get the same blank Dropdown result each time.

Can anyone please advise where things are going wrong?  Or can anyone please confirm that the below code is working in their environment?

Otherwise failing that, does anyone have another method of populating a Date dimension's property in a Dropdown?

Thanks

Anton

var dimDate = PlanningModel_1.getMembers("Date");
var CALMONTHmemberId = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);

for( var i = 0; i< dimDate.length; i++ )
	{		
		var currentCALMONTH = dimDate[i].properties.CALMONTH;
		if(CALMONTHmemberId.indexOf(currentCALMONTH) === -1 && currentCALMONTH)
			{
			   CALMONTHmemberId.push(currentCALMONTH);
			   Dropdown_CALMONTH.addItem(currentCALMONTH);
			}
	}

 

(Working solution - https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/sac-story-use-dropdown-for-dimension-property/qaa-p/14177305/emcs_t/S2h8ZW1haWx8dG9waWNfc3Vic2NyaXB0aW9ufE1FNldFWDlSNjVLNjF8MTQxNzczMDV8U1VCU0NSSVBUSU9OU3xoSw#M4922567)

entry.title: Re: Sales document type / Order type is not visible in T-...
entry.content:
To make Sales Document Type visible in J7LTSL, follow this structured approach:

Step 1: Activate SD Interface Mapping

Use Function Modules as under, not T-codes:

These FM's are part of IS-REA (Recycling Administration) and are used to map SD documents to REA categories. Ask your ABAP team to check if these FM's are active and properly linked in your REA customizing.

Step 2: Maintain REA Category Mapping

Use T-code J7L1 or J7L3 to assign REA categories to Sales Document Types and ensure correct mapping of item categories and REA condition types

Step 3: Check REA Document Type Settings

Use T-code J7L2 or J7L5 to define REA document types and link them to SD document types and REA categories

In short, the summary is

entry.title: Re: [SAP Crystal Reports Developer for Visual Studio] Ass...
entry.content:
Hi Charles,

Here's a few links to add to your favourite list:

All of the relevant info, What's new, what's been fixed, licensing, release notes, etc.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

Direct link to downloads:

https://origin.softwaredownloads.sap.com/public/site/index.html

There are multiple reasons why you should upgrade to the latest

1. As of the end of 2025 SAP will no long make 32 bit runtime available, time to build your project in 64 bit, no reason why to support 32 bit applications anymore since all PC mother boards support 64 bit applications

2. Security updates are embedded in latest SP's, this is for your own security and your users.

3. More important is the deprecation of 3rd party dependencies, Windows Framework versions and other 3rd party dependencies. Currently SAP CR for VS only supports 4.7 and 4.8 Framework, Microsoft has deprecated older versions and CR for VS follows Microsoft's supported runtime.

To assist you in upgrading see this blog I wrote:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrading-a-visual-studio-2008-gt-2022-net-project-with-the-latest-cr-net/ba-p/13469215

So to be Windows Compliant you really need to keep your project runtime updated to the latest SP's

Hope that helps and convinces you to upgrade to the latest SP 38 runtime.

Note: SP 29 is now 5 years old...

Don
